Genbank

Source: vignettes/genbank_flu_required_fields.Rmd
genbank_flu_required_fields.Rmd

Overview

In order to batch uploading meta- and sequence- data to Genbank using a NCBI UI-Less Data Submission Portal Protocol, SeqSender will need generate three required files:

  • a .zip or .tar.gz archive file
  • submission.xml which acts like an envelope to the submission and includes the necessary instructions on how to process this submission.
  • submit.ready which allows NCBI system to pick up new submission and start the submission process

In particular, a .zip or tar.gz file must include the followings:

  1. Sequence data (.fsa): nucleotide sequences in FASTA format.

A general description of the file:

  • sequence IDs must be unique for each sequence
  • cannot contain spaces
  • may contain only the following characters - letters, digits, hyphens (-), underscores (_), periods (.), colons (:), asterisks (*), and number signs(#).
  • should be under 25 characters

For more information, see https://submit.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/help/#fasta

  1. Source information table (.src): A tab-delimited metadata text file
  2. Authorset information (.sbt): Text file with submitter names and organizations, as well as publications associated with or describing the sequence.
  3. Structured comment table (.cmt): This is an OPTIONAL tab-delimited text file which can be used to provide additional sequencing technology and assembly information.

Organism of interest

  • Influenza Virus A (FLU)

Required files to run SeqSender

  • Config file (a yaml format, e.g. config.yaml)
  • Fasta file (a fasta format, e.g. sequence.fasta)
  • Metadata worksheet (a csv format, e.g. metadata.csv)

Config file

Config file is a yaml file that provides a brief description about the submission and contains user credentials that would allow SeqSender to authenticate the database prior to upload a submission.

Fasta file

Fasta File contains nucleotide sequences for all samples. See Genbank Fasta Format for more details.

Metatata worksheet

The metadata worksheet is a comma-delimited (csv) file that contains required attributes that are useful for the rapid analysis and trace back of Influenza Virus A cases. See Source information for Influenza sequences.

Required Fields Description
Sequence_ID Submitter Provided Unique Identifiers. Identifiers cannot contain any spaces.
subm_lab Full name of organization, institute, or laboratory, etc., who is submitting this record
subm_lab_division The division of organization, institute, or laboratory, etc., who is submitting this record
subm_lab_addr The address of organization, institute, or laboratory, etc., who is submitting this record
authors Citing authors. List of Last, First Middle, suffix separated by a semicolon “;” E.g.: “Baker, Howard Henry, Jr.; Powell, Earl Alexander, III.;”
publication_title The title and relevant publication details (volume, issue, etc.) of a paper that discusses the submission. If left empty, the program will used the name of the submission as title.
publication_status Options: “unpublished” or “in-press” or “published”
src-organism The most descriptive organism name for the samples. If relevant, you can search the organism name in the NCBI Taxonomy database. For FLU, organism must be “Influenza A Virus”.
src-isolate Identification or description of the specific individual from which this sample was obtained
src-collection_date The date on which the sample was collected; must be in the ISO format: YYYY-MM-DD.
For example: 2020-03-25
src-country Geographical origin of the sample; use the appropriate name from this list. Use a colon to separate the country or ocean from more detailed information about the location, eg “Canada: Vancouver” or “Germany: halfway down Zugspitze, Alps”. Entering multiple localities in one attribute is not allowed.
src-host The natural (as opposed to laboratory) host to the organism from which the sample was obtained. Use the full taxonomic name, eg, Homo sapiens
src-serotype For Influenza A only; must be in format HxNx, Hx, Nx or mixed; where x is a numeral
src-isolation_source Describes the physical, environmental and/or local geographical source of the biological sample from which the sample was derived.


NOTE: The prefix of “src-” is used to identity attributes for Source Information Table. Likewise, the prefix of “cmt-” is used to identity attributes for Structured Comment Table which is not mandatory.

To include additional attributes to Source Information table, just append src- in front of the desired attributes, e.g. src-subtype, src-passage, etc. See Genbank Source Table Modifier for more details.

To include additional attributes to Structured Comment Table, just append cmt- in front of the desired attributes, and most importantly, the fields must be sandwiched between cmt-StructuredCommentPrefix and cmt-StructuredCommentSuffix, e.g. cmt-StructuredCommentPrefix, cmt-Assembly Method, cmt-Coverage, cmt-Sequencing Technology, cmt-StructuredCommentSuffix. See Genbank Structured Comment for more details.
